background_dashed.customLabel: In Pre-school (<6 years old),  there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of PMI on Overall ASD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 6 studies exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of PMI on Social-communication. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 19 studies exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of PMI on Adaptive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 studies exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of PMI on Global cognition (IQ). Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 6 studies exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of PMI on Language (Expressive skills). Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 6 studies exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old),  there is no difference between PMI and controls on Language (Receptive skills). Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 4 studies exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old),  there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of PMI on Disruptive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 5 studies exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.
